revision.comment: [[:English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Tenses/Conitnuous Tenses]] moved to [[:English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Tenses/Continuous Tenses]]: typo
revision.text:
{{English contents}}
There are 3 main continuous tenses in English: '''present continuous''', '''past continuous''' and '''future continuous'''.
* Present continuous - this tense is used to talk about actions which are being done. In the sentence, "He is playing the game.", "is playing" is in the Present Continuous tense.
* Past continuous - this tense is used to talk about completed (or finished) past events which were being done '''continuously''' in the past. In the sentence, "They were winning the match",
* Future continuous - this tense is used to talk about offers, predictions and promises that will be done continuously in the future. This is done by using the word "will" or "shall" with "be" and the participle of the verb. In the sentence, "He will be getting the book.", "will be getting" is in the Future continuous tense.
[[Category:Types of word|Simple Tenses]]

{{wikipedia}}[[Image:A convertor free-bass piano-accordion and a Russian bayan.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Two types of accordions]]'''Accordion''' is a fun instrument to play. It is makes different sounds by pushing air over the reeds by using the bellows.
== Contents == * [[/Introduction/]] ** [[/Types of Accordions/]] ** [[/Inside an Accordion/]] ** [[/Why Play the Accordion?/]] ** [[/Brief History of the Accordion/]] * Playing the accordion ** [[/Right hand (Chromatic button accordion)/]] ** [[/Right hand (Diatonic button accordion)/]] ** [[/Right hand (Piano accordion)/]] ** [[/Left hand/]] ** [[/Free Bass/]] ** [[/Reed Ranks and Switches/]] * Techniques ** [[/How to Handle the Accordion/]] ** [[/Operating the Bellows/]] ** [[/Body Position/]]

[[Image:96_button_Stradella_bass_upload_(physical).jpg|thumb|right|250px|A 96-button Stradella bass layout on an accordion]] The '''Stradella Bass System''' (also called the ''standard bass'' sometimes) is a type of button layout you find on the left (or bass) side of most accordions. It uses columns of buttons arranged in a circle of fifths.
Each vertical column has, in order from left to right: * The major third above (or minor sixth below, depending on which note) the root ("counter-bass") * The root note * The root note's major chord * The root note's minor chord * The root note's dominant seventh chord * The root note's diminished seventh chord
This is a chart of how a standard, 120-button bass layout will look like:
[[Image:120-button_Stradella_bass_system_chart.png|thumb|center|750px]]
The middle "C" usually has a bump or hole in it for you to feel, to make it easier to find your way around the left buttons without looking at them.
Horizontal columns are arranged in a different order: every column goes up a fifth as you move up the keyboard, and down a fifth as you go down. So a "G" would be below middle "C", and a "F" would be above the middle "C".
Most full-size accordion basses have either 120, or, less commonly, 96 buttons. All notes in an octave are covered by both systems, so you can play in any key.
When playing with the bass buttons, you use all fingers but your thumb, which should stay on the board on the side of the accordion.

[[Image:Klaviatur-3-en.svg|thumb|right|300px|This is how a piano accordion keyboard looks.]]The right hand of a piano accordion is played the same way as you would play a piano, with usually the same fingerings. You can use all fingers, including the thumb, to play on this keyboard.
On most accordions, the range of the keyboard goes from the "F" below the middle "C", all the way up to the third "A" above middle "C".

''
Welcome to...
'''The Weather Project
''''' [[File:Thunder lightning Garajau Madeira 289985700.jpg|700px|center]]
{{Helpers|[[User:Juliancolton|Juliancolton]]}}

'''[[Weather/Content|Go to the contents page »]]'''
[[Category:Weather| ]]

==Contents of Weather==
===Storms and other weather systems=== * [[/Atmospheric pressure|/Atmospheric pressure]] * [[/Cloud|/Cloud]] * [[/Rain|/Rain]] * [[/Snow|/Snow]] * [[/Freezing rain|/Freezing rain]] * [[/Sleet|/Sleet]] * [[/Tropical cyclone|/Tropical cyclone]] * [[/Extratropical cyclone|/Extratropical cyclone]] * [[/Weather front|/Weather front]] * [[/Low pressure|/Low pressure]] * [[/Storm|/Storm]] * [[/Flooding|/Flooding]] * [[/Thunderstorm|/Thunderstorm]] * [[/Blizzard|/Blizzard]] * [[/Wind|/Wind]] * [[/Temperature|/Temperature]]
===Recording and forecasting the weather===
===Extreme weather===
===Climate change===
[[Category:Weather]]
[[Category:Geography|Weather]]

[[File:Pakkanen.jpg|right|thumb|A thermometer, a tool used to find the current temperature]] Temperature is the measure of how hot or cold the air is. It is commonly measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit. Temperature is very important for studying the weather.
Temperature may be affected by several things, including sunshine, ocean currents, and location.
The amount of sunshine at a certain place can change its temperature. The amount of sunshine a place has can be measured in "sunshine hours". That is worked out by the number of hours of daylight and how many of these are cloud-free.
The hottest temperatures on Earth are found near the equator. This is because the sun shines directly on it for more hours during the year than anywhere else. As you move further away from the equator towards the poles, there is less sunlight during the year and the temperature becomes colder.
Altitude is the height you are above sea level. The higher up you are, the lower the temperature will be. This is because air that is higher up is less dense than it is at lower altitudes and air temperature depends on its density. Usually, for every 1,000 meters higher you go the temperature will drop by 6.5° C.
Sea temperature changes slower than air temperature. If the temperature on land drops then the area next to the sea will be kept warmer for longer than areas inland. Because of this, islands have a less dramatic climate than continents. Different seas have different temperatures, allowing one side of an island to be a different temperature to the other side.
[[Category:Weather]]

[[Image:ButtonAccordeon.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A button accordion.]]A chromatic button accordion is a type of button accordion where the right side keyboard has rows of buttons arranged chromatically. They have either three or five (or very rarely six) diagonally-horizontal rows. Each row can play three successive chromatic notes.
[[Image:C-Griff.svg|128px|thumb|left|Chromatic button system (type C)]] [[Image:B-Griff.svg|128px|thumb|left|Chromatic button system (type B)]]Chromatic accordions are most popular in Europe and in Russia. In Russia, this instrument is usually called a "bayan" (in Russian: баян).
There are two main types of button accordions. In both types, the further away from the top of the keyboard you go, the higher the notes; the closer to the top, the lower.
In the "type C" accordion, the middle "C" is on the row furthest to the right. In the "type B" accordion, the "C" is located on the third row from the right.
Most chromatic accordions have two extra rows located to the left of the main rows. They play the same notes as the same buttons of the 1st and 2nd rows. This can be helpful when playing a hard tune because you do not have to change fingerings when playing in a different key, but only move your hand to the left a row or two and play with the same fingering.
Some Serbian chromatic accordions have a sixth row, but this is not common.

[[Image:Melodiebass.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Three systems]]The '''free-bass''' is a type of keyboard system that is found on some accordions. Unlike the Stradella-bass system, all of the buttons on a free-bass keyboard play single notes, not chords. The free-bass also has a bigger range of notes than the Stradella system, and it is easier to play out a tune with it. Because of this, the Free Bass system is used more often to play serious classical music, especially counterpoint (when two or more melodies are being played at the same time).
Some bass systems can switch between the Stradella and free-bass systems.

[[Image:Accordion (PSF).png|thumb|right|220px|How to hold an accordion.]] The bellows are the engine for making the sound in an accordion. They make sound when moved, in either direction. The accordion won't play if the bellows don't move.
The bellows should be on your left hand side. Usually, they should be moved straight out and down a bit. When pushing them back in, you should lift the bellows slightly and push them back in at a small upwards angle.
[[Category:Accordion|*]]

[[Image:Accordéon diatonique.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A diatonic button accordion]]A '''diatonic button accordion''' is a type of button accordion where the right keyboard only has the notes of diatonic scales in a small number of keys. The left, or bass side, usually contains the main chords of the instrument's key and their root notes.
Because diatonic accordions have only a few keys they can play in, and usually cannot play accidentals, they are very restricted in what they can play. Usually they can only play folk music and classical music that doesn't contain many accidentals or changes of key signature.

revision.comment: [[:Accordion/Reed ranks and switches]] moved to [[:Accordion/Reed Ranks and Switches]]: capitalise for conformity with other pages, this seems to be the norm
revision.text:
[[Image:Accordion right hand timbre switches.jpg|thumb|right|195px|A few right-hand manual register switches on a piano accordion. This one has three different voices.]]A '''reed rank''' inside an accordion is a full set of the reeds that are used to make different timbres. These reed ranks are located in the reed chamber. Most modern accordions usually have from two to four reed ranks on the right side and three to five on the left side that can be used by themselves or in different combinations to make different types of sounds. They're sometimes classified by the the instruments they imitate, for instance the clarinet, oboe, and bassoon stops. Some more expensive accordions can have up to five or even six different reed ranks on the right side.
The reed ranks can be changed by pressing buttons usually found on the side of the accordion.

[[File:Symbol neutral vote.svg|15px]] '''{{{1|Neutral}}}'''

When playing the accordion, the straps should be behind your shoulders. Your left arm should be between the bellow-strap and the board - tighten that strap so that it won't cut off your arm circulation, but not so loose that your hand will slip all over the place.
You can play the accordion either standing up or sitting down. When playing standing up, adjust the shoulder straps so that the bottom of the accordion is on level with your hip. Don't slouch over too much, keep your back straight, so that the accordion won't move around too much.

When lifting up and putting down your accordion, be very careful. You usually shouldn't lift it up by the straps because they might not hold all the weight.
Always store your accordion in a case if you can. This helps keep it away from humidity and other things that might damage the instrument. Try to keep it out of too much heat, cold, or humidity. The reeds inside the accordion might bend out of tune if there's too much humidity.
If you can't store the accordion in a case, then always place it sideways, with the bellows on the bottom.

{{wikipedia}}'''Rugby union''' is a form of rugby. It is played on a field similar to a [[football]] field. It is very fun to play.
==Contents== *[[/Introduction/]] *[[/Positions/]] **[[/Prop/]] **[[/Hooker/]] **[[/Lock/]] **[[/Flanker/]] **[[/8-man/]] **[[/Scrum Half/]] **[[/Fly Half/]] **[[/Centres/]] **[[/Wings/]] **[[/Fullback/]] *[[/Rules/]] **[[/ELV's/]]
{{stub}} [[Category:Games]]

Rugby union is a very fun game played outdoors. It is full contact, and is seen as very violent by a lot of people.
==Equipment==
Unlike American football, rugby players wear very small amounts of equipment. They usually have only a jersey, rugby socks, rugby cleats, and a mouthguard. Practises usually use simple drills, that only need equipment like pylons and a ball. The rugby ball looks very different from other kinds of balls. It is fatter than an American football, but it has a lot more grip.
===The Field===
A rugby field is 100 meters from one end zone to the other, and it is 77 meters across. The end zones are 22 meters long. The posts at either end of the field look like soccer goals on the bottom, with long posts coming up from the horizontal bar.
==Moving the Ball==
You cannot throw the ball forward in rugby, it always has to go backwards. You can kick the ball at anytime, but you have to be careful of offsides. Offside rules will be explained in the [[Rugby union/Rules|rules]] section.
==Scoring==
A '''try''' is scored by taking the ball into the end zone, and touching it down on the ground. A try is worth 6 points. After a try, the team kicker will kick the ball for an extra point. The place the kicker kicks the ball from depends on where the try was scored. You can also score a '''drop goal''' at any time in the game. All you have to do is drop the ball, and kick it once it bounces off the ground. If the ball goes through the uprights, your team gets three points. Finally, you can score penalty kicks. If the other team gets a penalty (your team gets the ball), you can '''kick for posts'''. The referee will set up a tee for you at the place where the penalty happened. If the ball is kicked through the uprights, your team scores three points.
[[Category:Games]]

There are ten different positions in rugby. Each team has fifteen players on the field at one time. The positions are:
<u>Forwards</u>
* [[Rugby union/Prop|Prop]] (2 people) * [[Rugby union/Hooker|Hooker]] * [[Rugby union/Lock|Lock]] (2 people) * [[Rugby union/Flanker|Flanker]] (2 people) * [[Rugby union/8-man|8-man]]
<u>Backs</u>
* [[Rugby union/Scrum half|Scrum half]] * [[Rugby union/Fly half|Fly half]] * [[Rugby union/Centres|Centre]] (2 people) * [[Rugby union/Wings|Wing]] (2 people) * [[Rugby union/Fullback|Fullback]]
[[Category:Games]]

Props are usually the some of the biggest players on the field. They are part of the '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]]'''. There are 2 props on the field per team.
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Support the hooker * Push back the other team * Hold the front row together
===In Open Play===
* Follow the ball, in order to support the runner * Mark and tackle the other team's big players * Be active in the [[Rugby union/Rules#Rucks|ruck]] * Be ready to run the ball into the other team's defense
===In Lineouts===
* Lift the [[Rugby union/Lock|lock]] into the air * Be ready to stop the other team if they steal the throw-in
[[Category:Games]]

The hooker stands in between the props in the front row of the '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]]'''. They also throw the ball in for '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Lineouts|lineouts]]'''.
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Hook the ball back with their feet ** This includes trying to steal the ball from the opponents, as well as: ** Hooking the ball back on your teams put-in. * Help push the other team back once the ball has been hooked
===In General Play===
* Follow the ball around, to support the runner * Be ready to run the ball into the other team's defense * Be ready to tackle the other team's big players * Be active in the [[Rugby union/Rules#Rucks|ruck]].
===In Lineouts===
* Call the play * Make a good throw-in
[[Category:Games]]

__NOTOC__ This book covers in depth all topics required for a standard first aid course, and also includes a section on advanced topics. The basics covered include: This book is about all topics needed for a usual first aid class, and also has a section on advanced topics. The main topics included are: *First assessment and CPR *Legal points of first aid, which includes problems and permission *Blood system emergencies, like bleeding, heart attack, and stroke (where blood stops coming to the brain) *Breathing emergencies, like asthma and shock *Injuries inside the body, like broken bones, chest injuries, and bleeding inside the body. *Burns, seizures, and other medical problems Please recognise that this book might have pictures of injuries and other body problems. The editors of Wikibooks do not promise that information in this book is true, but they try to keep the information right.

''This page is under construction'' {{recipesummary|Flatbread recipes|3|15 minutes|2|[[Image:Banana_on_pancake.jpg|300px|Pancakes]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Flatbread|Flatbread]]
'''Pancakes''' are a bread-like food made from a batter that is cooked on a hot pan. There are many different kinds of pancakes, such as blueberry and chocolate chip. Here are some easy pancake recipes:
==Pancakes from the beginning== ===Ingredients=== *1 cup flour *1½ teaspoon baking powder *1 small bit of salt *1 cup milk *3 eggs which have been split between yellow spot (yolk) and whites (the clear liquid) *1 tablespoon sugar. If you are using other things such as blueberries or syrup then you won't want to use sugar.
===Procedure=== #In a big bowl, stir all the dry ingredients (flour, baking powder, and salt) together until they are well-mixed (mixed good). #Pour in the milk and stir a lot until it is smooth. #Put the yellow spots (yolks) in the batter and stir them well, then put the "whites" in a smaller bowl. #[[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] whites until stiff and then [[Cookbook:Fold|fold]] into batter gently (skip this step for heavier pancakes or if 1 cup buttermilk is substituted for milk). #Pour ladlefulls of the mixture into a non-stick pan, one at a time. #Cook until the edges are dry and bubbles appear on surface. Turn; cook until golden. Yields 12 to 14 pancakes.
===Notes, tips, and variations=== # Serve with butter, maple syrup, fruit, Nutella, melted chocolate, jam or cheese. # Pancakes do not store well. # Use [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] instead of milk, or wholegrain flours instead of white. This will change the consistency of the final product (i.e. whole grain flours generally lead to a denser heavier pancake, so try mixing white and wheat in various proportions as suggested above to get the feel you want). # Add sliced fruit such as [[Cookbook:Banana|banana]] and [[Cookbook:Apple|apple]], or broken crispy bacon to the batter after pouring into the skillet and before flipping.
==Banana-Spirulina Pancakes (Vegan)== This is a recipe for '''Banana-Spirulina Pancakes''' that makes about 5-6 large pancakes (serves two people well).
===Materials===
*1¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Flour|Flour]] (check that label!) *2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Sugar|Sugar]] *2 teaspoons [[Cookbook:Baking powder|Baking powder]] *½ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] *About 1 teaspoon powdered [[Cookbook:Spirulina|Spirulina]] (optional, but recommended) *2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|Vegetable oil]] *1¼ cup [[Cookbook:Rice milk|Rice milk]] ([[Cookbook:Soy milk|soy]] might also work) *1 thinly sliced [[Cookbook:Banana|Banana]] (if you freeze the banana first, you can get very thin slices) *non-stick [[cookbook:skillet|skillet]], [[Cookbook:sauté pan|sauté pan]], or [[cookbook:griddle|griddle]] *[[Cookbook:Spatula|Spatula]] *[[Cookbook:Maple syrup|Maple syrup]] *non-stick spray
===Steps=== Sift and mix flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and spirulina in a big bowl. # In a separate bowl, mix oil and milk. # Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients. # Dump in the liquid ingredients and lightly mix the two together. # Do not whisk, beat, or otherwise try to mash out all of the batter lumps. You will end up with tough, flat, and ugly pancakes. Keep a light hand, and your pancakes will remember by yielding fluffy results. # Gently toss in the bananas and stir them just to coat in the batter. # Heat up the non-stick pan and spray evenly with oil. # Using a 1/3 cup measure as a scoop, dip into the batter and pour evenly into the [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]]. Watch your heat carefully, you want it on medium-hot (don't burn them). # When bubbles begin to form in the middle of the pancake, and the edges look somewhat set, give it another spray of oil. # Immediately, flip over. # Cook for another minute or so, then remove the pancake, and put it in the toaster oven on warm (Or find some way of keeping it warm while you finish off the batter). # Spray the pan again, and repeat until the batter is all gone.
===Serving Tips===
A light maple syrup is very good. Some prefer this without anything.

There are 2 locks on the field at one time. They are in the second row of the '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]]'''. They also get lifted in [[Rugby union/Rules#Lineouts|lineouts]].
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Keep the front row stable by backing up the props * Guide the ball to the 8-man with their feet * Provide a handhold for the flankers
===In General Play===
* Follow the ball, providing support for the runner * Be active in the [[Rugby union/Rules#Rucks|ruck]] * Be ready to run the ball into the other team's defense * Be ready to tackle the other team's big players
===In the Lineout===
* Responsible for getting the ball from the throw-in * Try to take the other team's throw-in * Is lifted into the air by props
[[Category:Games]]

There are 2 flankers on the field for each team. They hold onto the sides of the '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]]''' and are usually very fast.
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Push back the opposing team * Be ready to break off quickly to tackle the other team * Help keep the ball in the scrum using your feet
===In General Play===
* Be a tackler; ** Flankers are very defensive, they do a lot of tackling ** Mark everyone on the other team, big or small * Be active in the [[Rugby union/Rules#Rucks|ruck]]. * Follow the ball to support the runner
===In the Lineout===
* Be ready to tackle the other team if they win the ball
[[Category:Games]]

Football is a team sport - you cannot play it by yourself. There are 11 players on the soccer field at one time, including the [[Football/Content/Players|goalkeeper]]. Off the field, substitutions (players who can come on the field if a player is tired or gets hurt) and coaches (people who help teach the team) are a very important part of the group. Here is a list of some famous teams. == European Teams == *[[Liverpool]] *[[Chelsea]] *[[Manchester United]]
{{stub}}

[[:Cookbook:Hearty Beef Vegetable Soup]] moved to [[:Cookbook/Hearty Beef Vegetable Soup]]: Move to correct title; we don't have a cookbook namespace.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Soups|Soups]]
This is one of my favorites that my mom used to make for me.
==Ingredients== *1 pound [[Cookbook:Beef|beef]] round steak, cut into ¾-inch cubes *1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] *½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] *2 (13¾-ounce) cans [[Cookbook:Broth|beef broth]] *4 cups [[Cookbook:Water|water]] *½ cup sliced [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] *2 teaspoons dried [[Cookbook:Basil|basil leaves]] *1 (14½-ounce) can stewed [[Cookbook:Tomato|tomatoes]] *2 cups sliced [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]] *2 cups bow tie [[Cookbook:Pasta|noodles]] *2 cups torn fresh [[Cookbook:Spinach|spinach leaves]]
==Procedure== # In a 4-quart saucepan, over medium-high heat, brown beef in margarine. # Add onion; cook until tender. # Stir in beef broth, water, celery, and basil; bring to a boil. # Cover; reduce heat and simmer 1 hour. # Add tomatoes, carrots, noodles; bring to a boil. # Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered, 25 minutes. # Stir in spinach; cook 5 minutes more.
Makes 10 cups.
==Notes, tips and variations== * For a hearty stew, remove 1 cup broth from soup; stir in 3 tablespoons flour until smooth. Return to soup mixture; cook and stir until thickened.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

Requests for the [[m:bot|bot]] flag should be made on this page. This wiki uses the [[m:bot policy|standard bot policy]], and allows [[m:bot policy#Global_bots|global bots]] and [[m:bot policy#Automatic_approval|automatic approval of certain types of bots]]. Other bots should apply below. Older bot requests can be found in the archives of [[Wikibooks:Simple talk|Simple talk]]
==Current bot requests== ''None currently''
[[Category:Wikibooks]]

The 8-man stands at the very back of the '''[[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]]'''. There is only one on the field for a team at one time.
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Organize the scrum's push ** Often the forward captain * Control the ball when it comes back * Protect the [[Rugby union/Scrum Half|scrum half]] when s/he is passing
===In General Play===
* Follow the ball around, to support the runner * Be ready to run the ball into the other team's defense * Be ready to tackle the other team's big players * Be active in the ruck
===In the Lineout===
* Stands at the back of the lineout ** Often the tackler when the other team throws in/steals the lineout
[[Category:Games]]

{{archive header}} ==Bot flag requests== ===[[user:HermitBot|HermitBot]]===
I created a bot account, [[user:HermitBot|HermitBot]]. Hopefully I will be able to use the bot to help us out with boring task. You can take a lot at it at its user page. Thanks! [[user:HermitBot IV|HermitBot IV]], which welcomes new users automatically, and [[user:HermitBot III|HermitBot III]], which fixes common spelling mistakes and typos. Thoughts? ''''~''''''' [[User_talk:Wikihermit|Wiki]]hermit''' 02:54, 16 July 2007 (UTC) :::Great. :) However, on simple wikipedia (and others, I'm sure) they don't welcome users until they have a few mainspace edits. But since this wiki is so small, maybe there should be an exception... --[[user:Isis|'''Is''']][[user talk:Isis|'''''is''''']] 13:30, 16 July 2007 (UTC) (This bot was never flagged.) —[[m:User:Pathoschild|Pathoschild]] 06:07:26, 23 October 2009 (UTC)
===[[User:Mike's bot account|Mike's bot account]]===
I operate the same bot (flagged) on en.wb and en.wv. It is harmless - runs pywikipediabot and AWB to do common tasks. I'm going to request a flag at meta, and begin a run now. [[User:Mike's bot account|Mike's bot account]] 19:51, 9 February 2008 (UTC) :You can see planned functions on the bot's userpage. Now is the time to ask questions or comment on this bot. * Bot operator: [[User:White Cat]] ([[:Commons:User:White Cat]]) - En-N, Tr-4, Ja-1 * List of botflags on other projects: Bot has a flag on wikimedia (meta,commons) wikipedia (ar, az, de, en, es, et, fr, is, ja, ku, nn, no, ru, sr, tr, uz, simple...) (See: [[m:User:White Cat#Bots]]) * Purpose: Interwiki linking, double redirect fixing, commons delinking (for cases where commonsdelinker fails) -- [[User:White Cat|Cat]] [[User talk:White Cat|chi?]] 18:15, 14 March 2008 (UTC) :Looks fine to me, but I think you'll have to request it from a steward at meta, since we don't have a bureaucrat here. --[[user:Cromwellt|Cromwellt]]|[[user talk:Cromwellt|talk]]|[[Special:Contributions/Cromwellt|contribs]] 22:48, 30 July 2008 (UTC) :: (This bot was never flagged.) —[[m:User:Pathoschild|Pathoschild]] 06:09:25, 23 October 2009 (UTC)

Hi, I have setup [[User:MaximillionBot|MaximillionBot]] to maintain interwiki links and just tested it. Anyone object to me getting a flag for it? (I will have to request the flag on [[meta:|meta]]) (I might also set it up to do automatic archival of talk pages in the future) [[User:Maximillion Pegasus|Maximillion Pegasus]] 18:24, 18 January 2009 (UTC) :Just do it straight away. As far as I know, it just falls under what Global Bots would do. Let me check up on this, and I'll reply soon. Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 18:42, 18 January 2009 (UTC) ::Okai, at the moment the guys in #wikimedia-stewards are too busy purring to deal with my request :/. Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 18:49, 18 January 2009 (UTC) :'''Support''' - No problems by me. I will come with my bot soon (Not for interwiki but against vandalism) [[User:Abigor|Abigor]] 19:08, 18 January 2009 (UTC) ::Yay! All three active editors say yes. Off to go ask at [[m:]]. Abigor: We don't get enough vandalism, do we? And feel free to drop by #wikipedia-simple when you have the chance :). Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 19:11, 18 January 2009 (UTC) :::Ok, I've requested it at [[meta:Steward requests/Bot status]]. [[User:Maximillion Pegasus|Maximillion Pegasus]] 19:12, 18 January 2009 (UTC) {{done}} --[[User:Walter|Walter]] 23:13, 19 January 2009 (UTC) (steward) :Thank-you. Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 08:17, 20 January 2009 (UTC) ---- As an aside, what are our thoughts on implementing a "yes" to [[m:Global Bots]]? I'd say sure, as we need as much help as we can get :-) Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 21:52, 18 January 2009 (UTC) :I see no problems with activating global bots. But there isn't a lot of botwork going on here. [[User:Abigor|Abigor]] 05:52, 21 January 2009 (UTC) ::But maybe enabling gbots will increase the amount of bot work? Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 08:12, 21 January 2009 (UTC)
===[[User:ChenzwBot|ChenzwBot]]===
I'd like to propose a bot flag for Chenzw's bot, who is dutifully adding interwiki links. Although the bot does not run regularly, a random sample of the bot's edits shows that they aren't mistakes. I don't see any reason as to why we should not grant Chenzw Bot the flag, especially as it makes RC easier to patrol. To allow for the small community here, I propose that we do not apply at meta, until 28 days are up, or when most of our active(ish) editors have !voted. (at my count: MC8, Abigor, Yotcmdr, Bluegoblin7, Ezra Katz). Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 21:17, 8 March 2009 (UTC)` :Yep, I agree with this proposal. Cheers, [[User:Razorflame|Razorflame]] 21:19, 8 March 2009 (UTC) ::That was ''quick''. Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] 21:20, 8 March 2009 (UTC) :{{support}} [[User:Abigor|Abigor]] 14:15, 9 March 2009 (UTC) *'''Support''' – This is an excellent bot, and proven on other wikis. '''[[User:American Eagle|TheAE]]''' [[User talk:American Eagle|talk]] 06:19, 13 March 2009 (UTC) :Granted by me from meta --[[User:Mardetanha|Mardetanha]] [[user_talk:Mardetanha|talk]] 22:18, 14 March 2009 (UTC)
===[[user:Abibot|Abibot]]===
Hello, I would like to ask for a new bot bit for Abibot. Best regards, [[User:Abigor|Abigor]] 05:54, 13 March 2009 (UTC) *'''Support''' – Seems fine. It's doing good work. '''[[User:American Eagle|TheAE]]''' [[User talk:American Eagle|talk]] 04:53, 14 March 2009 (UTC) **Oppose: Abibot appears to be a welcome bot: this is not needed, as we are a small community -- humans come on here every so often; why do we need to have a bot to do it, when it is already being done much more personally? Also, I feel that such welcome bots *should* appear in RC. —Regards, [[User:Microchip08|Microchip08]] [[User talk:Microchip08|(talk)]] (This bot was never flagged.) —[[m:User:Pathoschild|Pathoschild]] 06:11:16, 23 October 2009 (UTC)

For now, I'll run a trial up to 100 edits. The scrum half passes the ball from the back of the [[Rugby union/Rules#Scrum|scrum]] to the [[Rugby union/Fly Half|fly half]]. He kicks very much and he also calls plays for the backs a lot. They are often the team captain.
==Responsibilities==
===In the Scrum===
* Put the ball in * Throw the ball to the fly half * Kick the ball from the scrum when they have to * Tell the [[Rugby union/8-man|8-man]] to "rush" the ball if they feel it is a good idea * Attack the other scrum half if it is the other team's put-in
===In General Play===
* Always speedy, runs the ball a lot * Be in the back line * Pass the ball out of [[Rugby union/Rules#Rucks|rucks]] * Be ready to tackle at all times
===In the Lineout===
* Sometimes calls the play * Gets the ball from the player that catches it ** They can run, pass, or kick the ball at that point * Attack the other scrum half if it is the other team's throw-in
[[Category:Games]]

[[File:Notes.svg|thumb|200px|Some musical notes.]] Music is usually written on paper on a [[staff]]. '''Notes''' on the paper tell the musician (the person playing the music) what to play and when to play it. Musical notes can also be used to show how long it is necessary to play something. Some people also call sounds that come out of an instrument "notes". Different types of musical notes include the "whole note", the "half note" and the "eighth note".

revision.text:
The columns of an abacus tell the different sections. The left section is for numbers 1-5 and once you reach the fifth number you move a bead to the right on the right section. After you move both right beads to the right you add a bead to the second row. You do this for all the math use needed.
[[Category:Abacus]]

revision.text: [[Category:Wikibooks]]

The outer core of the Earth is a liquid layer about 2,260 km thick composed of iron and nickel which lies above the Earth's solid inner core and below its mantle. Its outer boundary lies approximately 2,890 km (1,800 mi) beneath the Earth's surface]. The transition between the inner core and outer core is located approximately 5,150 km beneath the Earth's surface.
The temperature of the outer core ranges from 4400 °C in the outer regions to 6100 °C near the inner core. Eddy currents in the nickel iron fluid of the outer core are believed to influence the Earth's magnetic field. The outer core is not under enough pressure to be solid, so it is liquid even though it has a composition similar to that of the inner core. Sulfur and oxygen could also be present in the outer core.
Without the outer core, life on Earth would be very different. Scientists believe that convection of liquid metals in the outer core create the Earth's magnetic field. This magnetic field extends outward from the Earth for several thousand kilometers, and creates a protective bubble around the Earth that deflects the Sun's solar wind. Without this field, the solar wind would have blasted away our atmosphere, and Earth would be lifeless like Mars.

To play cricket you use: [[File:Cricket ball on grass.jpg|thumb|A red cricket ball.]] *A '''ball''': It is usually red or white. It is made of [[w:Cork (material)|cork]] and it is [[wikt:wrap|wrapped]] in [[w:String|twine]] and covered with [[w:leather|leather]]. It should have a [[w:circumference|circumference]] of 23 cm (9 inches). If it's a children's ball, it can be smaller. *A '''bat''': It is made of [[w:wood|wood]]. The wood is usually from the [[w:Kashmir|Kashmir]] or [[w:England|English]] [[w:willow|willow]] tree. [[w:Aluminium|Aluminium]] bats are not [[wikt:allow|allowed]]. The bat has a long [[w:handle|handle]]. One side is [[wikt:smooth|smooth]]. The bat has to be less than 38 inches (96.5 cm) long and 4.25 inches wide (10.8 cm). *The '''[[w:wicket|wicket]]''': There are two wickets on the pitch. Each one is composed of: :*The '''stumps''': They are 3 [[w:wood|wooden]] poles. :*The '''bails''': Two little wooden sticks [[wikt:place#Verb|placed]] on the stumps. *A '''boundary''': It is a [[w:rope|rope]] which [[wikt:define|defines]] the field. *A '''sight screen''': There are 2 sight screens. They are placed at the boundary. they are [[wikt:align|aligned]] [[w:parallel|parallel]] to the [[w:width|width]] of the pitch, behind each wicket.
<gallery> Image:Cricket Stumps en.svg|A wicket. Image:Boundary rope.jpg|A boundary rope. Image:Cricket bat.jpg|A cricket bat. Image:Benkid77 Birkenhead Park 2 090809.JPG|Two sight screens. </gallery>
[[category:Cricket|E]]

'''Regular expressions''' or '''regex''' are lines of code that let a computer read and understand text. Regex is used often because it can adapt to different changes in text lines, such as capital letters, typos, and length.
==Contents== #[[Introduction]] :*[[Welcome to Regex]] :*[[What you'll need]]

<[[Numbers/Content#Using_Numbers | Using Numbers]]
Now that you have learned about different kinds of numbers, it is time to learn how to use numbers to solve math questions.
==Questions you will learn how to answer==
*If a person has one book and another person gives him five books, how many books does the person have? *If you own 30 sheep and sell 12, how many sheep do you have? *If a person needs five liters of water a day to water her garden, how many liters will she need in two weeks? *You and two friends are sharing a bag of candy. How many pieces of candy would you get if there was 36 pieces in the bag?

{{English contents}} Verbs can come in many '''moods'''. The most important moods are: *[[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Indicative Mood|English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Indicative Mood]] *[[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Interrogative Mood|English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Interrogative Mood]] *[[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Imperative Mood|English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Imperative Mood]] *[[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Vocative Mood|English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Vocative Mood]] *[[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Subjunctive Mood|English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Moods/Subjunctive Mood]]
The moods describe different kinds of sentences, or different uses of sentences, that are usually in different forms. For example, ''interrogative mood'' is used when we make questions (use), and usually puts the [[English/Parts of Speech/Verbs/Auxiliary Verbs|auxiliary verb]] before the [[English/Word Functions/Subjects|subject]] (form). {{stub}}

revision.text:
{{wikipedia|Indus Valley Civilization}} '''Indus Valley''' (3000–1500 BC), one of the world's first civilizations (commonly known as "river civilizations" due to the fact that they all started out near a big river because it made living and supporting a whole city easier), was started on the banks of the Indus River in India.

==Geography== The Indus River Valley civilization was located in a small area of land in what is now Pakistan and India. Aside from being on the banks of the large Indus river, the Indus Valley civilization was surrounded by forests, desert, and ocean, making it a very fertile land.
==Cities== The Indus Valley civilization is well known for its two largest cities called Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro. These two cities were the largest of the 1000+ cities that have been found. Both Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro were centers of trade, and both had a very advanced city organization, including carefully organized houses, a sewer system, and major and minor streets, as well as warehouses used for storing food and merchandise and large city walls.
==Sciences== The people who belonged to the Indus Valley civilization had very advanced systems for telling time, measuring length, and weighing things. They also made beautiful art, including jewelry, statues and animals carved out of stone and gold, and musical instruments, toys, and games.
==Culture== The Indus Valley civilization also had a writing system. Although many people have tried to translate their writing into a language that we know today, nobody has been successful. They also had a religion as archaeologists have been able to find out from the carvings of some figure who is clearly a god and looks a bit like a Hindu god (Hinduism was worshipped in India much at a later period in history), but nobody knows for sure what their religion was or who their gods were.

[[Cookbook|< == Here is what you need: == '''Preparation Time''' - Half (1/2) an hour
'''Cooking Time''' - 1 hour
'''Feeds''' - This stew can '''feed up to 4 people'''. If you have a family with at least 5 people in it, you should make twice the amount of soup shown in the recipe (2 recipes worth).
=== Equiptment === You will need the following kitchen ''implements'' (tools such as a knife or a blender that can be found in your kitchen):
* A knife * A cutting-board * A large pot * A Tablespoon measure * A large stirring spoon * A measuring cup * A juicer === Ingredients === * 2 Onions * 4 Tablespoons olive oil * 8 Cups of water * 1/2 pound (half lb) of Red Lentils * 4 Tablespoons of soup mix (you can use any kind of soup mix, or if you don't have any, you can just leave it out) * 1 Teaspoon Cumin * 1 Teaspoon Coriander * 1 Lemon == Preparation == # Take the two onions, and peel them. Then cut them into small pieces. # Place the chopped onions into your big pot, along with the 4 Tablespoons of olive oil. # Saute (cook on low heat stirring often) the onions on low heat until they turn clear looking and slightly golden. # Drop the 8 cups of water into the pot with the onions. # Drop the lentils into the pot. # Carefully measure out the soup mix (if your using it) and drop it into the pot. # Carefully measure out the Cumin and the Coriander and put that into the pot too. # Stir the stuff in the pot, the turn up the temperature of the stove to about medium heat (you want it to be slightly bubbling, but not boiling). # Let it cook for an hour, stirring every few minutes to make sure that it doesn't burn. You may have to turn the temperature of the stove up or down a little. # After 1 hour of cooking, turn off the stove and put the pot on a different burner so that it doesn't continue to cook. # Take your lemon, and cut it in half. Then, squeeze it on the juicer until there is no more juice in the lemon. # Take the juice from the lemon, and put it in the pot. # Stir the pot, taste, and serve! [[Category:Cookbook|Cookbook]] [[Category:Stew|Egyptian Lentil Stew]]

revision.text:
[[Cookbook|<<Go back to cookbook contents]]
This is a nice soup to make. It tastes good both hot and cold.
==Ingredients== *1 [[w:Onion|Onion]] *2 Tablespoons [[w:Olive Oil|Olive Oil]] *2 [[w:Apples|Apples]] *1 [[w:Carrot|Carrot]] *1 [[w:Parsnip|Parsnip]] *1 [[w:Lemon|Lemon]] *4 cups of [[w:Water|Water]] *1 teaspoon [[w:Nutmeg|Nutmeg]] *1 large tablespoon [[w:Soup Mix|Soup Mix]] (optional)
==What to do== #Chop up the onions, and [[Cookbook/Saute|saute]] them in a pot with the olive oil until the onions are golden #Chop up the apples, the carrot, and the parsnip, and put them into the pot #Squeeze the juice from the lemon #Put the water, the nutmeg, the soup mix (if you are using the soup mix), and the juice from the lemon into the pot #Cook for one hour, or until the carrots are soft #Put the soup into a blender and blend it up until it is smooth: there should not be any lumps in it #Serve cold or hot!
[[Category:Soup|Apple Parsnip Soup]]

revision.text:
Canasta is a card game that is like rummy. It is played with two decks of cards, including jokers.
==Object of the Game== The object of the game is to get 5,000 points before your opponents. You get points for making canastas (300 or 500 points), red threes (100 points each, but 800 if you get all four), and for cards melded. You lose points for cards in your hand. Usually, 4-6 hands must be .
==Canastas==
==Gameplay==
==End of Game== The game ends when all cards have been drawn or a player "goes out". A player can go out if he has melded or discarded all cards in hand and has at least 500 points in canastas. When the game is ended, players get points for cards melded and lose points for cards in hand. Those points are
*Jokers: 50 points *Aces and 2s: 20 points *8, 9, 10, J, Q, K: 10 points *3, 4, 5, 6, 7: 5 points
